d1ac6d03e521680914d764e8449ef051 (02:48): hm.. any issues with VIA chipsets?

334980e1e056773993bf52426a66cdc9 (02:48): dunno, I've never done the x86

334980e1e056773993bf52426a66cdc9 (02:49): but I've done two new and two old world
d1ac6d03e521680914d764e8449ef051 (02:49): alright, what about package management?
d1ac6d03e521680914d764e8449ef051 (02:49): netbsd uses pkgsrc right?
334980e1e056773993bf52426a66cdc9 (02:49): apart for the 6500 who's OF would crash when I typed commands, it wasn't that bad
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (02:49): WhIcHOnE: I use pkgsrc on NetBSD.

592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (02:50): WhIcHOnE: I think ports is binary packages, but any more than that I couldn't tell you because I don't use ports.
d1ac6d03e521680914d764e8449ef051 (02:50): ball: alright, I think I'll give NetBSD a try :)
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (02:50): WhIcHOnE: that's the best way to determine whether you're likely to like it.
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (02:52): fwiw I like NetBSD.

0ec644d47e44c42cf93652fb776bdf84 (02:54): no idea about its stability state
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (02:54): (I run native drivers)

0ec644d47e44c42cf93652fb776bdf84 (02:55): also using open native drivers here
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (02:55): WhIcHOnE: which one? ;-)
d1ac6d03e521680914d764e8449ef051 (02:55): Belkin F5D7000-B with some kind of atheros chipset
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (02:55): I know that some atheros adaptors are supported.
d1ac6d03e521680914d764e8449ef051 (02:56): but it doesn't work with the FreeBSD built in kernel driver
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (02:56): You may need a custom kernel.  It's worth a try.

0ec644d47e44c42cf93652fb776bdf84 (02:56): try it out

d1ac6d03e521680914d764e8449ef051 (02:59): it shows up on slackware here as Atheros Communications Inc. Unknown Device 001a
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (03:02): hello fbsd1
d1ac6d03e521680914d764e8449ef051 (03:02): phadthai: how would I go about installing ndis w/o an internet connection?

0ec644d47e44c42cf93652fb776bdf84 (03:04): you might need to download a binary -current snapshot via ftp and burn it on a CD along with sysinst 2.88MB floppy used as el-torito boot disk when creating the CD image...
d1ac6d03e521680914d764e8449ef051 (03:04): hm ok, sounds complecated :|
0ec644d47e44c42cf93652fb776bdf84 (03:05): hmm I think I once saw docs on the site describing the process
0ec644d47e44c42cf93652fb776bdf84 (03:06): http://netbsd.org/Documentation/current/
0ec644d47e44c42cf93652fb776bdf84 (03:06): hmm I don
0ec644d47e44c42cf93652fb776bdf84 (03:06): 't see procedure there to make a cd though
0ec644d47e44c42cf93652fb776bdf84 (03:07): that's manual upgrade to -current using a previously installed netbsd system

0ec644d47e44c42cf93652fb776bdf84 (03:08): but basically, if you put all the snapshot files in same order on the CD, and specify to mkisofs the el-torito image of the 2.88MB floppy disk in it it should make a bootable image
d1ac6d03e521680914d764e8449ef051 (03:08): All my floppys are 1.44MB =[
0ec644d47e44c42cf93652fb776bdf84 (03:09): yeah usually a 2.88MB image is used to make bootable CDs
34bb67fbe51ecef3bc1bb4d04f912d3e (03:09): WhIcHOnE: ye we all know you arent 1337
0ec644d47e44c42cf93652fb776bdf84 (03:09): el-torito simulates a floppy boot
34bb67fbe51ecef3bc1bb4d04f912d3e (03:09): :p
0ec644d47e44c42cf93652fb776bdf84 (03:10): or actually, el-torito allows to specify which image to boot so bios can boot it off the CD
0ec644d47e44c42cf93652fb776bdf84 (03:12): ftp://ftp.netbsd.org/pub/NetBSD-daily/HEAD/200606220000Z/i386
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (03:12): WhIcHOnE: You might want to try 3.0 first, it should be easier (burn iso, boot CD...)
0ec644d47e44c42cf93652fb776bdf84 (03:12): check INSTALL.TXT three
0ec644d47e44c42cf93652fb776bdf84 (03:12): s/three/there/
0ec644d47e44c42cf93652fb776bdf84 (03:13): oh hmm no mention of details to make CD there either though
0ec644d47e44c42cf93652fb776bdf84 (03:13): but it's standard mkisofs + cdrecord commands of course
0ec644d47e44c42cf93652fb776bdf84 (03:14): in those, ftp://ftp.netbsd.org/pub/NetBSD-daily/HEAD/200606220000Z/i386/installation/floppy/boot-big.fs would be the file to use as el-torito boot image
0ec644d47e44c42cf93652fb776bdf84 (03:14): to specify in mkisofs
0ec644d47e44c42cf93652fb776bdf84 (03:15): i.e. mkisofs -b installation/floppy/boot-big.fs -o image.iso -r -J files/
0ec644d47e44c42cf93652fb776bdf84 (03:15): to create the bootable iso image
0ec644d47e44c42cf93652fb776bdf84 (03:16): just one
ce8a1609cf8d1a408da3cac46365f53e (03:16): need a -current iso?
d1ac6d03e521680914d764e8449ef051 (03:16): Ober: trying to figure out how to get installed / working
d1ac6d03e521680914d764e8449ef051 (03:16): phadthai: how just one?
0ec644d47e44c42cf93652fb776bdf84 (03:16): Ober: yes he wants to verify if he can get ndis working for his wifi

0ec644d47e44c42cf93652fb776bdf84 (03:17): WhIcHOnE: others are only for packages and are optional (although if connection-less for a while you might want to get the 3.0 CDs other than the first one, yeah)
0ec644d47e44c42cf93652fb776bdf84 (03:17): but one CD would be enough to know if your ath can work under ndis
d1ac6d03e521680914d764e8449ef051 (03:17): phadthai: I downloaded i386cd-3.0.iso
0ec644d47e44c42cf93652fb776bdf84 (03:18): that's the one you would be replacing with he -current CD
d1ac6d03e521680914d764e8449ef051 (03:19): ok so just put that iso away for now?
